shareMetaData.title: Make your constitution
shareMetaData.description: You start out with 100 choice points and can win up to 50 more if you answer everything right in the quiz. Then you can filter articles and finally select articles for you constitution and submitted as a vote.

en.heading: Make Your Constitution
en.text: Welcome to Make Your Constitution! You are going to experience what it is like to frame a constitution for a country of your choice, representing the political needs and desires of the citizens of that country to make for a long lasting, stable society with a contented electorate. Think you can do it?

en.youHaveAnAutoSavedGameFrom: You have a saved game from:
en.whatConstitutionIsTheMostSimilarToYours: What constitution is the most similar to yours
en.automaticInfo: Cards for your country plus random cards
en.win: Swipe through cards manually to win
en.createYourCountry: What country is the constitution for?
en.culturalAttitude: The cultural attitudes of your country
en.question: Question
en.youHaveCompletedTheQuiz: You have completed the quiz and can now go ahead to create your country and then filter your favorite constition articles
en.youHaveCompletedTheFiltering: You have completed the filtering of articles and can now proceed in assembling your own constition using your choice points
en.orEnterApostCodeThatBelongsTo: Or enter a postcode that belongs to
en.forThisCodeYouCanVoteHere: For this code you can vote here
en.thisPostCodeDoesNotBelongTo: This postcode does not belong to
en.enterValidPostcode: Enter a valid postcode for this vote
en.confirmAge: Confirm that you are 8 years or older
en.favorite_info: Use ❤️ for your favorite idea = two votes
en.share_vote_by_pressing: Share the vote with your friends!
en.choose_a_neighbourhood_2: Choose a neighbourhood to cast your vote. 450 million have been allocated proportionately.

en.error_cant_connect: Can't connect to server, please try again later
en.error_could_not_post_vote: Could not post vote, please try again later

en.thank_you_2: Please only vote once. If you do decide to vote again only your final vote will be counted.
en.thank_you_3: The results of the vote will be published on the Gorbals Ideas Fund website www.gorbalsideas.org.uk
en.number_of_votes: Number of voters in this neighborhood
en.select_favorite: Select favorite for a double vote

countryList.name: Happy Arctic Island Nation Now (Iceland)
countryList.description: Behind just a few of their Scandanavian cousins to the East on the list of the world’s happiest nations, these island people are an engaged, educated, industrious, forward-thinking, largely homogeneous population in the throes of redesigning their constitution. Can you help them?

countryList.name: Nordic Peninsular Kingdom 1849 (Denmark’s June 5)
countryList.description: Against the backdrop of revolutions sweeping other Western European nations, with the territorial questions around Holstein and Schleswig threatening to boil over, and on the advice of his dying father, Fredrick VII undertakes the major step of relinquishing his absolutist monarchy, and framing a constitution to take Denmark into an era of fledgling democracy. Do you think you could do a better job than he did?

reviews.highNetBonuses: You have captured the spirit of the middle of the 19th Century, with the right balance of continuity with the traditions of the past, while anticipating the needs of the future. You must be an excellent student of history and a fan of the original Rigsdag.
reviews.breakEven: You might have done better if you were shooting for the Danish constitutions of 1866 or even 1915 -- but for 1849 you may have over shot your mark. You answered some of your retro-Dane needs, but not all. And here comes the First Schleswig War!!!
reviews.highNetPenalties: Perhaps you misunderstood the assignment of designing a constitution for a European state transitioning from an Absolute Monarchy 170 years ago, to something resembling a fledgling democracy. You were wildly off, and the document does not match the spirit of those times. øv bøv!

countryList.name: 13 Colonies 1783 (US Constitutional Convention)
countryList.description: A rag-tag band of diverse colonies join together to defeat one of the most powerful maritime Empires in the world at that time; shocked at their own victory, they are determined not to have won the War, only to have lost the Peace. They set out to frame a document that will provide for a future free of the tyranny and injustice they had just endured at the hands of Mad King George II. Can you do as good a job as they did, or perhaps even build a more perfect union?

reviews.highNetBonuses: The circle of 13 stars has never looked more unbroken; you did a banner job framing a constitution that even Jefferson and Hamilton would have been proud of.
reviews.breakEven: It was sweltering hot that Summer in Philadelphia, and it looks like you felt a little heat trying to frame this constitution. Expectations of a population 250 years ago are very different from our assumptions about human rights and the Rule of Law today, and you did not meet those 1783 social needs.
reviews.highNetPenalties: Well, what the British could not defeat, you have managed to drive down and demoralize. Your choices in constitutional design have left the colonies at odds and anger in the streets. Don’t be surprised if one of the other Founding Fathers challenges you to duel with pistols.

countryList.name: ‘Murica Now (US currently)
countryList.description: The first Democratic nation in the world, this nation has grown from 13 to 50 states since its constitution was first written. It rode the wave of Economic development following World War 2 to become the undeniable Super Power of the 20th Century; now it finds itself floundering in a constitutional crisis at the beginning of the 21st. Help this nation write a new constitution that reflects the new nation it has become!

reviews.highNetBonuses: A nation torn apart by political strife and polarization may in fact find healing in your document, as it seems as if you did strive to find “a more perfect union.” You have brought a democracy back from the brink, taking dark money out of politics, and creating an atmosphere of compromise wherein neither side feels the need to cheat in order to win.
reviews.breakEven: You did not craft a perfect fit for the country torn apart by reality show politics and memes designed by foriegn intelligence agencies to disrupt democracy. You gave it a good try, and perhaps some people would be happy with this document; it doesn’t quite save the day, however.
reviews.highNetPenalties: Well, you wrote a decent constitution -- if you were writing for one side of a civil war. The constitution you wrote favors one side of the argument on many topics, and as such, will not work to bring the country back together. If your document became the law of the land, you would have the real risk of plunging the country into a Second American Civil War.

countryList.name: Islamic Revolutionary Republic 1979 (Iran at fall of Shah)
countryList.description: After the Fall of the Shah, the Ayatollah Khomeini returns from exile in Paris with a rough draft of a constitution that mixes elements of the Quran and the Fifth French Constitution; it goes through many revisions as the Islamic Revolutionary movement crafts a Theocracy that reflects the cultural values that lead them to revolt against a Shah propped up by the infidels in the CIA. Think you understand a population like that well enough to frame a constitution they will think is just and righteous?

reviews.highNetBonuses: The mullahs and the people on the streets of Tehran agree; you have provided for a Muslim Theocracy that nonetheless has a modern democratic face turned to the world, demonstrating that both religious faith and political wisdom can co-exist in the law of the land.
reviews.breakEven: Though you showed adequate respect to Islam, you may have crafted a document too friendly to Western values and jurisprudence. This may create tensions for the Persian people in years to come. Perhaps this is a functional document for their government, but you did not achieve a perfect fit for the political tastes of this population.
reviews.highNetPenalties: The people of this ancient mountainous region did not rise up in revolution, driving that CIA puppet the Shah out of power, just to have you come here and write this unholy sell out constitution! Once the word gets out that infidels have butchered the writing of the constitution, you may want to follow the Shah’s lead and get the first plane out of Tehran for Paris.

countryList.name: Jolly Island Kingdom Now (Brexit Era UK - time to codify?)
countryList.description: It’s a certain Kingdom that’s not looking very “United” these days -- can a well engineered 19th Century Constitutional Monarchy with an uncodified jurisprudence tradition make it in the 21st Century? Could you codify their constitution for the future to make a better island nation?

reviews.highNetBonuses: It seemed risky to write a codified constitution for Europe’s oldest and most successful uncodified constitutional monarchy. In the aftermath of Brexit, the Jolly Kingdom’s parliament showed paralysis and inaction in the face of the true existential threat posed by the referendum. The reforms you have made have fixed that, and got the country on the right track. Jolly good show!
reviews.breakEven: You gave it the old public school try with a stiff upper lip, but like the many Conservative MPs before you, it looks like you may have just signed on for more of the same. Though your document makes many improvements, it seems as if many of the underlying divisions among the electorate remain, and that it’s going to take more than a codified constitution to get this Kingdom out of this mess. Keep calm, and carry on.
reviews.highNetPenalties: A Kingdom once United threatens to rip apart at the seams in the 21st Century -- and you wrote a constitution that will definitely speed that along. Your document does little to improve the distrust of the citizens, the paralysis of the parliament, and the animosity toward the rest of the EU. Your choices for laying a legal framework going forward were perfectly tone deaf, and will likely only make things worse. Bullox!

countryList.name: Pseudo-Communist Asian Superpower Now (Mainland China)
countryList.description: Once this nation was Chung-Kuo, the Middle Kingdom, the center of the universe. After a tumultuous history of 19th Century abuse at the hands of the colonial powers, and a 20th Century of war, famine, and autocratic rule, at the beginning of the 21st Century it is poised to become the greatest economic superpower the world has ever known, while internal democratic forces threaten to tear its autocracy apart. Can you imagine a new constitution for the future of the world’s most populous nation?

reviews.highNetBonuses: Crafting a democratic constitution for the most populous country in the world after 70 years of communism was a very tall order -- and you pulled it off! You showed adequate respect for the population’s need for structure and stability, while still opening up their civil society some. Long life and prosperity to you!
reviews.breakEven: Confucian meritocracy forms a core of political thought in the history of this country, and for your efforts in crafting this document, Confucious would give you about a C+. Some concerns of the billion plus citizens were addressed, but many more were left without guarantees of resolution. Better luck next time, grasshopper.
reviews.highNetPenalties: The hundreds of millions of city dwellers, and that many more in the countryside, with constant social upheavals in the last 70 years -- these citizens have been through a lot. Sadly, if the document you wrote was implemented for this population there would once again be a revolution in the streets, because it is unacceptable to the population in many ways. You did not find the Tao of constitutions.

countryList.name: Future Land (Imaginary Utopian State)
countryList.description: Dream of a perfect world, where everyone is equal, lives their lives in peace and tranquility with little suffering and injustice? Well, here’s your chance to design a constitution for such a brave, new land.

reviews.highNetBonuses: We asked you to imagine a better world, and you delivered. You understood what sort of legal frameworks would help a society move to the forefront of social justice and progressive ideals. Looking forward to those 15 hour work weeks and that Basic Minimum Income! Cheers!
reviews.breakEven: You understood some of the vision of Future Land, but not all of it. The document you framed addresses some of reforms the utopians would want in their society; but in other areas you came up short. When it comes to imagining a perfect world, you are a little less than perfect.
reviews.highNetPenalties: These imaginary utopians came to you for help framing a constitution that would help them construct a new kind of society -- and you pretty much screwed them over across the board. Where they wanted progress, you gave them retrograde and stringent jurisprudence. Your lucky these citizens are imaginary, because there’s nothing worse than getting a beat down from a bunch of utopians.

countryList.name: Splinter State (Imaginary Anarchist State)
countryList.description: Does the modern world seem like a terrible prison of rules, expectations and oppression? Do you yearn for a world with less structure, less people in your face telling you what to do? Well here is a country full of punk rock activists that want to live like you do! Can you design a constitution that holds this crazy kingdom together?

reviews.highNetBonuses: We asked you to understand the needs of punk rock activists, and it turns out you know all about hard core. Fewer rules, more rights -- it’s hard for The Man to keep you down if his hands are tied behind his back. The anarcho-syndicalists are happy with you and have invited you to join them in the mosh pit!
reviews.breakEven: Well, true activist types are used to receiving compromise and half-measures in response to their demands, and that’s what you have given them once again. You have made many concessions in the direction of personal liberty and human rights, while still leaving the State with too much centralized power for the tastes of these hard core citizens. The shards of this Splinter State remain unsatisfied.
reviews.highNetPenalties: The document you created for this brave Splinter State of anarcho-syndicalists would immediately be spray painted, stomped on, and burned in effigy along with a straw dummy of you. Your traditional legal authority and State Power is seen as classic sell-out of everything your citizens stand for. These imaginary radical activists plan to have sit-in protests in your dreams, in a campaign they call Occupy Your Conscience.

highBonus.high: Your citizens craved a structured, top down society, and, boy, did you give it to them. They will be certain who the boss of their government is, and they have demonstrated that they like it that way.
highBonus.medium: In regards to the hierarchical structure of your government, you struck a sober balance between the need for clear leadership, and the rights of the individual. Your citizens feel they have the right amount of guidance from their government, and the right amount of self determination.
highBonus.low: The electorate let you know that they wanted government out of their lives, not telling them what to do, and you listened. You crafted a lean government that attends to the affairs of the State, and does not tell its citizens what to do otherwise.

breakEven.high: Well, some of your constituents are happy, while some feel you have crafted a document that will not provide clear enough leadership from the central authority. That may prove tough for you at the ballot box.
breakEven.medium: Some citizens think you found a balance of citizens rights and the authority of the state, while some think you have given the state the ability to overreach in people’s lives.
breakEven.low: Although you made some concessions in the direction of government that was hands-off, small and lean, you did disappoint some stakeholders. Thus, you still face some strong opposition that feels your document gives the State too much power.

highPenalty.high: What were you thinking? A paralyzed central government that never gets anything done? What good is that? The people of your society want strong, bold clear leadership, and you have given them a kangaroo court and a patty-cake parliament. Don’t expect to win any elections anytime soon.
highPenalty.medium: When it comes to a balance of governmental and civil power in society, your constitution is more a see-saw than level playing field. Some areas have too much overreach, while others are set to be completely unregulated. In this area, you failed to deliver the balance so important to your citizens.
highPenalty.low: Your constitution has sparked great controversy among your constituents -- they think it’s a bunch of regressive, strong man BS!! How dare you impose so much order and structure on their day to day lives? This is not what they signed on for, and they are scrambling to try to block or rewrite your document.

highBonus.high: When your libertarian constituents spoke, you listened. They didn’t want a government that could get up in their grill about seat belts or smoking or what they do on their own property. And it looks like to them like you framed a document that will give them their freedom for many years to come.
highBonus.medium: You framed a document that matched your country’s attitude on personal freedoms -- for common sense matters, public safety, airport security, seat belts -- you provided for  government’s necessary role in keeping people safe. In other areas, you left people to their own devices, and your citizens dig that.
highBonus.low: People wanted a government capable of curtailing the excesses of a chaotic and lawless population, and you gave it to them! They didn’t want people acting out in the street, breaking laws, throwing chewing gum on the sidewalk, and you framed a legislative and judicial powerhouse designed to keep people in line. This should insure you have the orderly support of the electorate in the future.

breakEven.high: Libertarians are a hard bunch to please, and your constitution predictably only pleased some of them in your country. In framing a system of laws that give the government some reach, you have threatened their sensibilities in the name of a stable, functioning society. Let’s hope you have enough political capital to continue selling them on this compromise in the future.
breakEven.medium: Resolving the balance of personal liberties and addressing issues of security and public safety has proven tricky for you in framing your document. You have some constituents who feel you may have gone too far, others who say you didn’t give law enforcement enough powers. Hopefully your document can maintain this balance going forward.
breakEven.low: Reactionary elements in your society have complained slightly about the broad range of freedoms you have protected in your document. Though not immediately threatening to them personally, they do feel like you have left the door open for an anti-social element in your society to destabilize life in the country in the future. Time will tell if you can ease their fears.

highPenalty.high: You call this a constitution? My government’s document that was supposed to make me feel like my personal freedoms had been kept safe? I would not use this constitution to wrap fish and chips, not worth the paper its printed on; go back to the drawing board and give us a document that actually helps keep us free.
highPenalty.medium: In a country with people on both sides of the issue of personal freedoms versus a secure, safe society, you managed to piss off everyone on both sides. Couldn’t have blown it worse on this topic if you set out to fail intentionally, congrats.
highPenalty.low: Your society wanted discipline and structure, and instead you took them to a futuristic rave party in your constitution. They do not trust how much space you’ve given the libertarians and anarchists to mess around in the society doing their thing; that’s not how they would have wanted it framed, and they may riot for more restrictive legal defenses of the public safety and civil order.

highBonus.high: Your society places utmost esteem on scientific progress, and you created a constitution that underscores this attitude perfectly. The legal structure you laid out favors a future-looking electorate that wants the government to support and champion the sciences, and they applaud you for it.
highBonus.medium: You sought to balance the value of scientific discovery to your society, and the concerns of some segments of the electorate that this would infringe on the rights of those practicing religions that dispute science -- and your document found a way to balance that conflict that was welcomed by both sides.
highBonus.low: In framing your document, you took into consideration the deep skepticism your society feels towards the rapid pace of change in the modern era. They do not want rocket ships on their flags, or evolution taught in their schools, and you made them feel safe from both of those possibilities.

breakEven.high: For a society of futurists, you may not have framed a document that places adequate emphasis on scientific progress. Some have supported your cautious approach, while others think you have put legal tradition ahead of the cutting edge of human advancement.
breakEven.medium: As a country with a mix of modern secular and older spiritual beliefs, the document you framed met some, but not all, of your citizens hopes and fears about the future. Critics on both sides say your attempt to thread the needle to please everyone may lead to further tensions for the fledgling government.
breakEven.low: On the topic of material culture, you have attempted to drag a citizenry content to live in the past, somewhat kicking and screaming into the future. While not demanding modern dress or that every kid learns astrophysics in school, your framing did challenge a population of vintage sensibilities with a fresh set of rules.

highPenalty.high: And as for how your constitution acknowledges the achievements of modern science -- which is to say, it pretty much doesn’t at all -- you have set the country back with this document. The citizens feel like they are stuck governing a modern country with a set of caveman rules.
highPenalty.medium: The document you framed simultaneously offered too much support for retrograde ideas opposing the sciences, while also advancing enough forward looking amendments to alarm the hardliners. In trying to find a balance on technology and religion, you just pissed off both sides further. Good job, you’re a regular political genius.
highPenalty.low: What infidel document is this? How can you have thought that such a godless and vapid  document could rule a righteous and unsullied a population as ours? Your citizens feel they were clear that they wanted to keep evil technology and scientific nihilism out of their government, and you betrayed them.

highBonus.high: The anthem of the nation is playing, women in traditional dress dance on the steps of the capitol while you ratify your excellent constitution, and everyone toasts with a glass of ancestral celebratory wines of your country. The document you wrote will help guarantee these traditions are all preserved.
highBonus.medium: State holidays for great historic men and women, and the maintaining of the statues of these leaders of the past; even though your citizens  recognize times are changing and that some traditional ways must be abandoned, you provided the right balance of continuity with the past.
highBonus.low: Eliminating state support for outmoded religions and backwards cultural institutions was the right break with the past for your citizens, and your constitution was forward looking for providing for it. Your secular population doesn’t need to wear the wooden shoes of their ancestors to know who they are as a people.

breakEven.high: People wanted a little more respect shown to the old ways of the Fatherland, and the document you framed does drag the country into the modern world. Hopefully over time, the rumblings from the traditionalists in the electorate will quiet down.
breakEven.medium: Do people love traditions and the past? They do. Do they also love new stuff and how it changes things? You know they do. Did your document try to please both sides? Yes, yes it did. Was it successful? Um; mostly?
breakEven.low: The government you framed has inspired the imaginations of people about what a futurist government could be, while not entirely delivering on the promise in its actual articles. Some critics have pointed this out, but it seems you mostly got away with it.

highPenalty.high: This constitution has sold out a great heritage, the citizens feel, and they hope your document never becomes law of the land.   Who will answer for your violating the great traditions of your people?
highPenalty.medium: In a time when many are afraid of the future while others welcome it, you hoped to find a balance for your citizens. But you put too many idols on the chopping block, and now the population wants more respect for its traditions.
highPenalty.low: As far as having a population that’s ready for New World Order, you really took your poor constituents on a ride; they hate the backward looking, medieval law school nonsense that you have framed for them. Good luck facing them at the ballot box.

highBonus.high: One of the most important principles your citizens wanted upheld by your document was the greater good of the nation as a whole, and you delivered. The legal framework you laid out promotes prosperity for all, and limits individual excesses and transgressions.
highBonus.medium: The apple cart of the State cannot be knocked over by one bad apple; but the right of every apple to make it to market unbruised is also important to the apple vendor. In this way, your constitution struck an excellent balance between the common good and individual exceptionalism.
highBonus.low: Your people did not want a constitution that called on them to sacrifice for the common good, and you respected that. Keeping taxes low, and recognizing the rights of the individual to their own resource management was key in the document you framed, and your electorate appreciates that.

breakEven.high: As a society that has more followers than leaders, you framed a daring document, that does more for the rights of the individual than your constituents would probably approve of. You will have to convince them over time that you did the right thing.
breakEven.medium: When weighing the good of the many versus the good of the few, we may find ourselves at the same ethical cul-de-sac as King Solomon, tempted to make compromises that make no one happy. Your constitution reflects this, and your constituents have made an uneasy peace with that.
breakEven.low: For a culture that doesn’t favor sacrifice, your constitution does ask a lot of its citizens; however, you managed perhaps to not have it ask TOO much. Time will tell if your legal framework, in which their rights are respected, but they are asked to contribute as well.

highPenalty.high: How can the center hold when every man only thinks of himself? The population of your country thinks you have given way too much power to the individual, and sacrificed the common good in doing so, and they cast ashes over their heads, and throw shame in your direction!
highPenalty.medium: The nail that sticks out gets hammered, the old proverb says. The question then is, who swings the hammer? The government you framed did not answer this question to the liking of your electorate, who thinks it neither provides enough for the common good, nor sufficiently protects the rights of the individual, whether they be nail, or hammer swinger.
highPenalty.low: The citizens took one look at what this constitution demanded of them, and they said, “you’ve gotta be f@!%@ kidding!” These are free spirited, independent minded people who view their relationship with the state as a loose allegiance. You have asked too much of them, and they will not be friendly to your document.

highBonus.high: On matters of diplomacy, your citizens were clear -- your country comes first, and that self-interest trumps any alliance with foriegn powers. You facilitated that outlook by framing a constitution that allows for bold Executive and Legislative action to unilaterally advance the nation’s agenda at any time. You are bound to get re-elected so that you can get out there and Manifest some of that Destiny.
highBonus.medium: In the course of human events the good of the nation must always be balanced with the good of the entire world milieu. Your moderate electorate understands that, and you constructed a document that perfectly matches their beliefs. Your balanced approach has guaranteed their support in the future.
highBonus.low: A country that embraces the modern age understands that in an ever-increasing tide of global interactions each individual state must be nimble and enthusiastic about potential allegiances, and with your constitution, you gave them just that. In your framing, your country’s diplomatic corps has all the tools it needs to fashion fantastic coalitions of like minded globalist planet savers.

breakEven.high: Well, it’s safe to say that the “My Country First” crowd, which is strong in your constituency, will never be completely happy. But you gave them enough guarantees of intact sovereignty that they will give your document a passing grade.
breakEven.medium: As for how your document deals with diplomacy and trade, your constituents have not seemed too engaged; they are seemingly content that you managed to forge a balance of safe borders and stable trade that will at least maintain the status quo.
breakEven.low: The citizens of your country wanted preparedness for outreach and engagement with the outside world to be easily pursued by the terms of your constitution, and they were half satisfied, half disappointed.

highPenalty.high: Unfortunately, your constitution’s broad and expansive attitudes toward diplomacy, trade and treaties, all have your citizens in the streets chanting, “Globalist Pigs!! Selling Our Country Out!! Internationalist Dogs!!” -- you’ve heard it out your own window. It will make it hard for the government you’ve framed to proceed on the world stage with this visible lack of support at home.
highPenalty.medium: You may have thought your electorate wanted a balance of domestic focus and global outreach out of its government, but it seems somehow you got the mix just wrong. Where people wanted protection they feel exposed, where they wanted to reach out, they feel you’ve denied them the opportunity. A frustrating disappointment on this front.
highPenalty.low: Your country’s citizens are cosmopolitan, they like to think of themselves as citizens of the World as well as citizens of their little corner of it. And your constitution went and ruined that, making them feel cut off from the world, behind lines of tariffs and red tape. This means the document will probably be challenged on the topic diplomacy and trade in the future.

highBonus.high: In this age of high tech surveillance, your constituents were very concerned that your document would sufficiently curtail the power of the State to monitor their daily lives. You addressed those concerns beautifully, reassuring them that what goes on in behind bedroom windows is no business of any branch of government.
highBonus.medium: Your country’s understanding of the relationship between protecting citizens’ private information and monitoring some forms of communication to provide for the security of the public allowed you to frame a constitution that balanced these concerns. Your constituents are pleased with your document on this front.
highBonus.low: What do people have to hide -- that’s what your citizens want to know. People don’t need privacy if they have done nothing wrong. Your document understood that, and foregrounded the State’s mission to provide for public safety over any sanctimonious concerns about personal information.

breakEven.high: Given the current information economy, and the way citizen consumers regularly expose their data to the world, some demands for privacy from the electorate are unrealistic. And your constitution treated them that way, which was not entirely satisfying to your privacy loving constituents
breakEven.medium: As your country wanted a balance of their privacy concerns with the needs of law enforcement to protect the public; upon reviewing your document, the jury of public opinion is still out on whether you have achieved that. In essence, you preserved the status quo, which your electorate was not entirely happy with.
breakEven.low: The citizens of your country preferred security to great concern over protecting their personal data. You did not grant the State all of the extraordinary powers of investigation the most conservative elements of your society wanted, but you didn’t tie the hands of law enforcement much, either. Overall your constituents are cautiously satisfied on this issue.

highPenalty.high: When polls show that 90% of the country wants an end to government surveillance of its citizens, and you go frame a constitution that provides numerous back doors and loopholes to do just that -- you have an angry mob on your hands. And an election coming up where you will likely find yourself out of power.
highPenalty.medium: The citizens of your country wanted a balance of security and privacy, and they feel like you haven’t given them either. In places where they wanted their data secure you’ve left them exposed, and you’ve “protected” them in places they find inconvenient. Overall, a fail on that front.
highPenalty.low: You protected criminal’s personal information at the expense of free citizen’s lives. The public is not impressed with your fascination with the rights of people who might perpetrate violent crimes. They are willing to sacrifice their privacy for that assurance, and you failed to give to them. On this issue, your document is dead on arrival.

highBonus.high: Your country wanted safe streets, an end to lawlessness, and a strong and empowered police force. You framed a constitution that provided for exactly that. The electorate will sleep easily at night knowing that they are protected by a thick blue line.
highBonus.medium: In the eyes of your electorate, the police need to have enough power to do their jobs effectively, but not one bit of power beyond that. Your document threaded this needle perfectly, and the citizens are happy with that.
highBonus.low: It’s not that your citizens hate cops, it’s just that they feel a whole lot better when they’re not around. Given that, the minimalist approach to policing that your document asserts fits the needs of your electorate perfectly.

breakEven.high: For a country that loves strong police presence in their communities, you gave them few guarantees that they would always enjoy that with your document. Though you did nothing to actively undermine law enforcement, there is still some suspicion and cynicism among your citizens that you had their backs on this particular topic.
breakEven.medium: Your country values safe streets and drivers that follow the speed limits; they also value citizens rights with regard to arrest and prosecution. The constitution you framed was a little light on reassurances on either front, leaving a sense of insecurity among your electorate. Not a deal breaker for you in the polls, but not a good look in the opinion columns either.
breakEven.low: You have a population that hates to be told they have to wear seatbelts -- a good indicator of libertarian ideas about policing in society. Although your document does not increase the power of the police, it does little to improve citizens’ rights and protections in cases of arrest and prosecution. By leaving the status quo largely intact you played it safe, while not winning any real brownie points from voters.

highPenalty.high: How can you have a civil society if the legal system cares more about the rights of the criminals than the rights of the victims and other innocent citizens? Your constituents feel like you gave law enforcement a very short shrift in your constitution, and they are ready to make you pay for it.
highPenalty.medium: Your electorate wanted a balance of an empowered police force, and the civil rights of the individual; you managed to make them feel as if you gave them too much of both. In places you tied the hands of law enforcement, while in other areas you gave them the opportunity for great abuse of power. Either way, the public is not happy with your document on this issue.
highPenalty.low: When the citizens can look you in the eyes and say they do not feel safe with the kind of cops that you have on the beat today, and you go and frame a constitution that gives the police even greater power to act without oversight -- this is not a document that most of your citizens will support. Your electorate is sick and tired of abuse at the hands of law enforcement, and they see you as making the situation worse when you promised to make it better.

highBonus.high: You understood that you were framing a constitution for a nation of social justice warriors, and you did not disappoint. Your legal framework puts human rights first, the power of the State second, and that’s exactly what your electorate wanted. Peace, love, and democratic participation, baby.
highBonus.medium: In these times of rapid social change, your centrist electorate wanted you to find a balance between civil rights and the deeply held beliefs of some segments of society. You framed a document that allowed for this splitting the difference, ensuring no one was disenfranchised, and no offense was given to the more conservative segment of the population.
highBonus.low: Your electorate did not want to be dragged kicking and screaming into the 21st Century; they had some more old school notions of how they wanted their government to act. You recognized this, and did not push them to embrace any overreach of civil rights or reparations to any minority groups. This has greatly improved the popularity of your document with your society.

breakEven.high: Social justice warriors will never be completely satisfied, and for the constitution you framed, you decided that had to be ok. You gave them some, but not all, of what they wanted, and you trust that they will continue protesting outside your office for the rest of it for all eternity, and for now that doesn’t seem like its going to hurt you too much in the polls.
breakEven.medium: Your constitution underscored the gains that have already been made in civil rights in your country, and laid a clear path forward for more progress, which may have annoyed more conservative elements in your electorate. But by not actively advancing any radical new set of civil rights provisions, you are able to break even on this matter.
breakEven.low: Constitutions can be aspirational documents -- unfortunately, your electorate doesn’t aspire to much. You have tip-toed around the issue of social progress in your document, arising the suspicion of the clergy and other conservative pundits -- but in the greater public’s eyes, you advanced nothing radical, and this amounts to a shrug.

highPenalty.high: When confronted by the cries of your population for greater social justice, you turned a numb cheek and a blind eye. The constitution you composed did not meet the minimum standards of compassion and humanity that your electorate demanded. In the history of legal documents, this one will go down as a work of shameful oppression.
highPenalty.medium: It’s a neat trick to manage to both offend conservatives by promoting social progress and egalitarianism, and social justice warriors for your curtailing of the same rights -- but you managed it! Neither side is happy with the compromise you struck, and it does not bode well for the future of your document.
highPenalty.low: How do you justify throwing away thousands of years of teachings and deeply held beliefs, all for the fashionable social mores of the current world? How dare you write a constitution that enshrines the rights of these marginalized people at the expense of the smooth functioning of the status quo? Your constitution leads us down that primrose path, and your citizens are NOT having it.

modules.name: Executive Branch
modules.description:
You can delegate authority, but you cannot delegate responsibility
(Byron Dorgan)

modules.name: Head of State: Empowered President
modules.description: An Empowered President, elected directly or indirectly by the entire electorate, meant to personify the will of the people in single individual's leadership abilities.
modules.bonus: High Authority,High Independence,High Law and Order
modules.specialFunctions: Blocks Prime Minister, King, High Priest, Enables Vice President

modules.name: Head of State: Prime Minister
modules.description: As the head of the Legislative/Parliamentary system, the Prime Minister’s authority arises from the elected representatives choice of a leader amongst themselves. This helps reduce gridlock in government, while also disconnecting the Head of State from the direct will of the electorate.
modules.specialFunctions: Blocks Empowered President, High Priest, Vice President

modules.name: Head of State: King
modules.description: Historically the center of authority in pre-modern governments, the King's authority rests on a traditional architecture of original military conquest, hereditary transitions of power, and usually some notion of Divine Will. Though once always autocratic and ruling through all powerful fiat of their will, many monarchs have ceded power to more democratic and parliamentary governments, becoming largely figureheads of continuity and tradition.
modules.bonus: High Authority,High Tradition,High Collective,High Law and Order
modules.specialFunctions: Blocks Empowered President, High Priest, Vice President

modules.name: Head of State: High Priest
modules.description: In a proper Theocracy, the central authority rests with the highest authority of the clergy of the religious faith that underpins the government, the spiritual leader of the majority of the population of the country. This authority may function as an interpretive and judicial authority primarily; or it may be an absolute autocratic authority over all structures of government.
modules.bonus: High Authority,High Tradition,High Collective,High Law/Order,Low Science
modules.specialFunctions: Blocks Empowered President, King, Vice President

modules.name: Figurehead Executive: Vice President
modules.description: Whether elected individually or packaged with a President on a "ticket", the VP gives the electorate the comfort of knowing they have chosen a worthy successor to the President, and a smooth transition of power is guaranteed should something unexpected happen to the chief executive. The VP position is also a valuable political actor for diplomacy and affairs of state.

modules.name: Figurehead Executive: Figurehead President
modules.description: In the case of the Head of State being a Prime Minister, King or Supreme Theocrat, then there might be an executive position called President, that may be appointed or elected, and generally performs public relations for the government, as well as matters of diplomacy and affairs of state.

modules.name: Cabinet: Appointed by Head of State
modules.description: Sometimes called the "to the victor go the spoils" approach, this allows the Executive Head of State to compose a team of cabinet members that they select, insuring a team of like minded individuals likely to work well with the Head of State and each other. Comes with increased risk of cronyism.

modules.name: Cabinet: Appointed by Legislature/Parliament
modules.description: In a Prime Minister's cabinet the factions in the legislative body may also control the staffing of the PM's cabinet. This helps the government be as integrated, coherent and internally conflict-free as possible.

modules.name: Veto Power
modules.description: The ability of the Executive to serve as a check on laws generated by the Legislative/Parliamentary Branch. This gives the Executive a roll of oversight of the law making process, thus giving them the chance to lead from a "bully pulpit" against popular opinion if the new law polls well, or to function as an agent of that public opinion as their elected Executive in stopping an unpopular law.

modules.name: Term Limits
modules.description: In the case of an Empowered President, this provides for a set number of terms to which the executive may be elected, usually limited to no more than 2 or 3 terms, and usually no more than 4 to 6 years in length.

modules.name: Age Requirement
modules.description: Sets a minimum age for the Head of State/chief executive, making life experience a key requirement for service as national leader.

modules.name: Meritocracy Requirement
modules.description: Sets requirements of achievement for prospective candidates for Head of State, in professional, academic, and political life as qualifications for public service as Head of State. This may involve actual objective testing, or evaluation by a peer review panel.

modules.name: Conflict of Interest Constraints
modules.description: Sets a constitutional prohibition against any business or organizational ties that might pit the Head of State's self-interest against the interest of the State.The Head of State must not abrogate their loyalties, and their commitment to the public good must be beyond question.
modules.bonus: High Collective,High Progressivism,High Law and Order

modules.name: Emoluments Prohibition
modules.description: The Head of State must not be allowed to accept gifts from foreign entities who might be trying to use such gifts to sway foreign policy decisions that the Head of State should make without such influence.

modules.name: Power of Executive Orders/Royal Decree
modules.description: Confers to the Executive branch the authority to issue edicts/executive orders/decrees that function roughly the same as laws passed by the Legislative/Parliamentary Branch, though they generally sunset when the Executive goes through a transition of power.

modules.name: Religious Authority
modules.description: Confers on the Head of State authority over the state religion, and the ability to make decrees that have both religious and legal significance to the society.
modules.specialFunctions: Additional bonus in combo with High Priest

modules.name: Control of Taxation/Budget
modules.description: The Branch that has this power makes the ultimate decisions on the government's revenue sources, funding allocation and debt and deficit management, the so called "power of the purse."

modules.name: Control of Military
modules.description: The Branch with this authority functions as the sole civilian oversight and command of the government's defense force and standing army, if any.

modules.name: Control of Diplomacy
modules.description: This conveys on the Branch the responsibility of negotiating treaties, appointing ambassadors, maintaining trade relationships and open lines of communication with neighboring countries and international allies alike.

modules.name: Authority to Declare War
modules.description: Gives the Branch the sole authority to formally engage in hostilities with another nation state.

modules.name: Authority to Sign/Ratify Treaties
modules.description: When the fruits of either war or diplomacy generate a lasting legal document of new relationship between the government and another state or multiple state actors, this confers on the Branch the ultimate authority for confirming these agreements as the law of the land.

modules.name: Control of Police Forces
modules.description: With this framing, the government institutes a federalized power structure for its police enforcement, and for the oversight of local policing efforts and prosecutorial authority. This delegates which Branch has oversight and executive control over this chain of command.

modules.name: Executive Authority: Powerful and Sweeping Authority
modules.description: Head of State and or government can form policy and make decisions without much interference by Legislature or courts.
modules.bonus: High Authority, High Law/Order, High Independence, Low Progressivism
modules.penalty: High Progressivism, Low Law & Order, Low Authority

modules.name: Executive Authority: Technocratic Authority
modules.description: Government ministers and key officials seek to form policy on a professional basis avoiding ideological considerations. Experts play a big role in evaluating government actions.
modules.bonus: High Science, Medium Collective, Medium Law & Order, Medium Authority

modules.name: Executive Authority: Majority Dependent Authority
modules.description: The government rests on parliamentary support and must coordinate policy- and decision making with parliament. Government action must have clear legal basis.
modules.bonus: HIgh Collective, High Progressivism, Medium Science

modules.name: HoS Selection: Popular Vote Election
modules.description: The Head of State is elected by the people for a on term at a time. There may be restrictions on the number of terms the same head of state can stay in office.
modules.bonus: Medium Progressivism, Medium Tradition, Medium Science

modules.name: HoS Selection: Parliamentary Election
modules.description: The Head of State is chosen by the legislature.

modules.name: HoS Selection: Hereditary Position
modules.description: The Head of State is disconnected from the political process, but may still have a political role.

modules.name: Legislative Branch
modules.description:
Now and then an innocent man is sent to the Legislature…
(Kin Hubbard)

modules.name: Basic Organization: Unicameral
modules.description: Creates a Legislature or Parliament with a single house representing the entire electorate, either by regional or proportional representation. When this body agrees on something and successfully executes its processes and procedural requirements, the matter being voted on becomes law immediately. This allows the body to be more nimble, and to have a greater appearance of society on a level playing field.
modules.bonus: High Progressivism,Low Tradition,High Liberty,Bonus for Population < 10M

modules.name: Basic Organization: Bicameral
modules.description: Creates two chambers or houses of legislative debate and process, generally one more directly democratic ("lower"), and the other more representative of the entrenched power in the society ("upper"). Laws generated in either house must be reconciled with both bodies, creating oversight and forcing compromise by different interests. This tends to promote stability and durable legislation.

modules.name: Representation: Proportional Distribution
modules.description: The electorate creates the legislative body by voting for candidates and/or parties in a national election, and the proportion of the national vote by party/candidate affiliation determines the balance of power in the legislative body. If no one party achieves a majority, a coalition government of compromise become necessary.

modules.name: Representation: Regional Empowerment
modules.description: Each region/province/state/municipality holds elections for its specific representative, that then go to the capital to form a government to decide the national interest.

modules.name: Representation: Hybrid
modules.description: This frames a balance between popular vote and regional representation, usually giving an outsized influence to smaller rural areas with entrenched interests that feel they would be drowned out in a straight popular vote.

modules.name: Procedures: Laborious & Byzantine
modules.description: This frames the parliamentary procedure for the legislative body or bodies as almost impossibly complex, by layering committees, requiring super majorities, enforcing deliberation periods, barring amendments or revisions to bills, etc. This makes the legal system stable and unreactive, favoring the status quo.

modules.name: Procedures: Elaborate & Stringent
modules.description: Here we frame what some would think of as the "right" amount of procedural forced debate and ability of a minority party to force compromise or revision in the deliberative process. This process reconciles chambers' divergent bills and filibuster tactics, while still allowing the function of law making to go on at a reasonable pace.

modules.name: Procedures: Functional & Expedient
modules.description: Here we frame the most nimble legislative body, usually unicameral, that has few impediments to swift up and down votes to enact new laws. This makes it very responsive to public opinion if that opinion is represented by the elected officials; unfortunately it does allow for a majority party to rapidly change the legal landscape with little recourse to the minority parties in opposition.

modules.name: Change Constitution: Very Difficult
modules.description: This means it requires multiple very unlikely political conditions to come together to allow for the constitution to be altered in the future. Supermajorities in all chambers, unanimous consent across all branches, majorities among all local and regional political actors, and possibly popular vote referendum for final confirmation. This insures the constitution's guarantees of rights and due process cannot be easily stripped; it also means government is less nimble in confronting societal change.

modules.name: Change Constitution: Difficult
modules.description: This frames changing the constitution as high bar, with a supermajority OR regional majorities and/or public referendums. It seeks to find the balance between stable rule of law, and capacity for the law to adapt to a changing society.

modules.name: Change Constitution: Expedient
modules.description: This frames a constitution that can be modified generally with simple legislative procedure, allowing the framework of the law to evolve with the society in real time, making the government both agile in addressing public opinion, and vulnerable to norms being dismantled by demagogues and autocrats.

modules.name: No Confidence Vote
modules.description: This allows the parliamentary body to call a floor vote on whether or not the body has confidence in its leadership, and generally demands a snap election.

modules.name: Quorum Requirements
modules.description: This demands that a minimum number of representatives of any given chamber must be present in order for the business of the chamber to proceed. This is meant to force attendance and engaged debate; it also gives members of minority and opposition parties the ability to hijack the process by not showing up to vote.

modules.name: Lobbying Constraints
modules.description: This codifies in the constitution limits on contributions from private and corporate interests to representatives, and limits on former representatives becoming lobbyists. To be effective in protecting the will of the people from being sold to special interests it must carry stiff penalties for those caught violating these constitutional rules.

modules.name: Power of Oversight/ Investigation
modules.description: This conveys the power to the legislature of review, investigation and oversight of all political activities the Executive and Judicial branches.

modules.name: Impeachment Powers
modules.description: This frames the Legislative/Parliamentary branch as the authority over Heads of States or members of the Judiciary who have violated laws or norms as set forth in the constitution. Specific parliamentary procedure is laid out, with its own due process; the case for and against the removal of the political actor is made, and a vote that determines their removal or survival.

modules.name: Power to Repeal Executive Orders
modules.description: Akin to a "reverse veto", this frames the authority of the legislative body or bodies to repeal or reverse the legal and political effects of an Executive Order/Edict/Decree of the Executive Branch.

modules.name: Public Access/ Oversight/ Audit
modules.description: This frames a constitutional process for the public to review legislative action and question process and methods in law making. Regional and/or municipal bodies will appoint auditors, who will address/enforce any ethical and accounting transgressions in full public review.

modules.name: Ombudsman
modules.description: This appoints an individual as chief ethics officer for the legislative body, final authority on matters of conduct, propriety and functionality of the parliamentary process.

modules.name: Control of Taxation/Budget
modules.description: The Branch that has this power makes the ultimate decisions on the government's revenue sources, funding allocation and debt and deficit management, the so called "power of the purse."

modules.name: Control of Military
modules.description: The Branch with this authority functions as the sole civilian oversight and command of the government's defense force and standing army, if any.

modules.name: Control of Diplomacy
modules.description: This conveys on the Branch the responsibility of negotiating treaties, appointing ambassadors, maintaining trade relationships and open lines of communication with neighboring countries and international allies alike.

modules.name: Authority to Declare War
modules.description: Gives the Branch the sole authority to formally engage in hostilities with another nation state.

modules.name: Authority to Sign/Ratify Treaties
modules.description: When the fruits of either war or diplomacy generate a lasting legal document of new relationship between the government and another state or multiple state actors, this confers on the Branch the ultimate authority for confirming these agreements as the law of the land.

modules.name: Security Council
modules.description: The government and/or the head of state must by this appoint a council to oversee and consult the government on security related issues including military matters. This ensures that proper analysis and specialist advice is used in policy-making.
modules.bonus: Low Independence, High Authority, High Law & Order, High Science

modules.name: Central Bank
modules.description: An article on a Central Bank ensures that an independent institution makes key decisions to influence economic conditions such as on interest rates based on an economic assessment, thus transferring certain decision-making power to experts.
modules.bonus: Medium Independence, High Science, High Collective

modules.name: Religous Organization
modules.description: Depending on a dominant religion this article requires that an organisation representing this religion is funded and maintained by the state. Other religious organisations may exist and be eligible to state funding, but the state has a responsibility to ensure that this one organisation provide religious services to its adherents.
modules.bonus: High Tradition, Low Science, High Collective
modules.penalty: High Progressivism, High Science, High Liberty

modules.name: Health Care System
modules.description: The state is responsible for running a health care system that provides basic medical services to the whole population. It may coexist with a privately run health care service.
modules.bonus: High Science, High Collective, High Progressivism
modules.penalty: High Liberty, Low Collective, Low Progressivism

modules.name: Public Elementary Schools
modules.description: This article makes it a requirement for the state to run elementary schools to ensure that everyone has access to quality education.
modules.bonus: High Science, High Collective, High Progressivism
modules.penalty: High Liberty, Low Collective, Low Science

modules.name: Speaker of Parliament
modules.description: A member of Parliament is elected to serve as the head of Parliament to ensure that it follows established procedure and to represent the Parliament at home and abroad. In the absence of Head of State the Speaker of Parliament may assume his/her duties as well.
modules.bonus: Medium Authority, High Collective, Medium Tradition

modules.name: Parliamentary Committees
modules.description: An article or articles on parliamentary committees establishes an order in the way legislative bills (and possible resolutions) are handled in order to increase professional assessment and the engagement of all factions within the legislature whether minority or majority representatives.

modules.name: Veto Override
modules.description: A supermajority in Parliament (e.g. two thirds) can override a veto issued by Head of State on legislation or resolution.

modules.name: Publlic Initiatives
modules.description: The public can present legislative initiative to Parliament. A certain percentage of voters must participate in a petition, usually somewhere between 2 and 5%

modules.name: Executive Initiatives
modules.description: The legislature must accept a proposal for legislation directly from the Head of State.
modules.bonus: High Authority, High Law/Order, High Independence, Low Progressivism

modules.name: NGO Initiatives
modules.description: According to this article established Non-Governmental Organizations’s have the right to propose legislation to parliament which it must then consider.

modules.name: Judicial Branch
modules.description:
There is a higher court than the courts of justice and this is the court of conscience. It supercedes all other courts.
(Mahatma Gandhi)

modules.name: Authority: Independent Judiciary
modules.description: This frames a Judicial Branch that has full equal authority to the Executive and Legislative Branches; it may preside over the rule of law, legislation and executive orders, judging their validity and viability based on constraints of this constitution and traditions of jurisprudence, striking them down if needed.

modules.name: Authority: Subordinate Judiciary
modules.description: With this framing, the judiciary is subordinate to the Executive and/or Legislative/Parliamentary Branches, performing in an interpretive and advisory capacity, focusing on executing and enforcing the laws.

modules.name: Judge Assignment: Appointed
modules.description: Judges are appointed by the Executive, Legislative/Parliamentary or regional authorities. This makes the Judiciary more in synch with the political climate of the government, reducing conflict between branches, increasing risk of political cronyism.

modules.name: Judge Assignment: Elected
modules.description: Judges are elected directly by the people, meaning they are responsive to variations in public opinion in the electorate, and less beholden to the political makeup of other Branches.

modules.name: Judge Assignment: Hybrid
modules.description: With this framing, judges come to the bench through a combination of direct election in some strata of the judiciary, and appointment in others, usually arranged in a tiered system that allows regional elected judges to review decisions by appointees, and vice versa.

modules.name: Judicial Jurisdiction: Federalized
modules.description: This frames a judiciary that is top-down from a central government. If judges are elected, it is in nationwide elections; federal jurisdiction presides over matters down to regional courts.
modules.bonus: High Law & Order,High Authority,Bonus for Population < 50M

modules.name: Judicial Jurisdiction: Regional
modules.description: This frames a judiciary that builds its authority from regional courts upward, with precedent decided on the local level, and central courts adjudicating national matters based on consensus ruling among regional top jurists.

modules.name: Judicial Jurisdiction: Hybrid
modules.description: This frames a bifurcated system in which areas of jurisdiction are divided between regional and federal matters, with the courts having a tiered review process in which regional and federal jurists may challenge one another over interpretation and enforcement of the law.

modules.name: Habeas Corpus
modules.description: A core principle of jurisprudence from the High Middle Ages, this frames the citizens' right not to be tried in absentia, that the defendant must be present to arrange for their defense, and confront witnesses brought against them.

modules.name: Supreme Court
modules.description: This frames the top of the judicial tiered system of courts as the ultimate final arbiter of the rule of law, able to overrule or strike down the legislation and orders/edicts generated by the Executive and Legislative/Parliamentary Branches.

modules.name: Universal Legal Standing
modules.description: Confers unto all citizens the equal protection and entitlement to due process under the law, regardless of gender, property or class.

modules.name: Elected Public Prosecutor/ Attorney General
modules.description: Constructs the position of the government's top law enforcement official as a position directly elected by the people, rather than a political appointee. This gives the electorate the ability to set the tone for enforcement and justice climate of the society.

modules.name: Religious Foundation of Jurisprudence
modules.description: This ties the constitution's framing of the rule of law to a religious text or creed, with a pre-existing set of legal codes, which become the foundation for jurisprudence for the judiciary of this government. All new laws must build on this framework, or are unconstitutional by this framing.

modules.name: Control of Police Forces
modules.description: With this framing, the government institutes a federalized power structure for its police enforcement, and for the oversight of local policing efforts and prosecutorial authority. This delegates which Branch has oversight and executive control over this chain of command.

modules.name: Civil Branch
modules.description:
The Good of the People is the Greatest Law
(Cicero)

modules.name: Suffrage: Universal
modules.description: Every citizen above a certain age (usually between 17-21) has the right to vote regardless of race, gender, class or property.
modules.specialFunctions: Blocks Land Owners Only, Men Only

modules.name: Suffrage: Land Owners Only
modules.description: Frames the electorate as landed property owners only, on the principle that only those paying property tax have "bought in" to the system, creating a class-based limited electorate, usually favoring a status quo.

modules.name: Suffrage: Men Only
modules.description: Frames the electorate in terms of a regressive patriarchy, allowing only men to vote.

modules.name: Citizenship: Automatic by Birth
modules.description: Frames into the constitution the right of jus sanguinis, or the blood right of birth in place, conveying on the individual irrevocable rights of citizenship.
modules.specialFunctions: Blocks Generational/Ethnic Group Only, Rigorous Application Only

modules.name: Citizenship: Generational/ Ethnic Group Only
modules.description: Creates a tiered system of citizenship, requiring multiple generations of immigrant ancestory before full citizenship is conveyed upon the descendent of the original immigrant.
modules.bonus: High Law & Order,High Tradition,High Border Density
modules.specialFunctions: Blocks Automatic By Birth, Rigorous Application Only

modules.name: Citizenship: Rigorous Application Only
modules.description: An exclusive meritocratic framing of citizenship that requires all citizens to pass a test to certify their citizenship and attain all rights to voting and legal standing.
modules.bonus: High Science,High Border Density,Bonus for Population < 10M
modules.specialFunctions: Blocks Generational/Ethnic Group Only, Automatic By Birth

modules.name: Citizenship: Hybrid
modules.description: Creates a more complex constitutional approach to citizenship, with some combination of resident alien, partial citizenship, birthright citizenship and naturalization through meritocratic application in tiers to accommodate as many residents of the nation's situations as possible.
modules.bonus: High Science,Medium Border Density,Medium Law & Order,Medium Progressivism
modules.specialFunctions: Blocks Generational/Ethnic Group Only, Rigorous Application Only

modules.sub_category: Balance of Federal/ National Regional Power
modules.name: Balance of Power: Federal Autocracy
modules.description: Creates a government in which all authority rests with the central state, and all civil legal matters between citizen and government are resolved with this centralized authority.
modules.bonus: High Authority,High Law & Order,Medium Science,High Independence

modules.sub_category: Balance of Federal/ National Regional Power
modules.name: Balance of Power: Federal - Regional Combination
modules.description: Divides authority for resolving civil matters with citizens between a federal authority and regional authority, carving out different areas of jurisdiction for each, with differences between regions allowing for minor variations in design and application of the law, while leaving matters of basic civil rights to federal resolution.
modules.bonus: Medium Authority,Medium Law/Order,High Science,Medium Independence,Bonus for Size > 1M sq Km

modules.sub_category: Balance of Federal/ National Regional Power
modules.name: Balance of Power: Regional Autonomy
modules.description: Frames a government with a weak central authority whose main focus is on international diplomacy and national defense, without much control or influence over the rule of law on the regional and local level. Presupposes fiercely independent regions bound together by loose coalition of neighbors with differing cultural needs.
modules.bonus: Low Authority,Low Collective,Low Independence,High Liberty,Bonus for Size > 1M sq Km

modules.name: Search & Seizure/ Probable Cause
modules.description: Frames the right of the individual not to be searched without a warrant or other legal due process around the concept of "Probable Cause". Meant to protect the citizen from unnecessary harassment by law enforcement.

modules.name: Right to Equal Treatment Under the Law
modules.description: Confers on the citizen the right of civil equality, which can be enforced against any discrimination based on class, race, gender, orientation or ethnicity by the government or other civil individual or cultural actor.

modules.name: Right to Security
modules.description: Frames the government's responsibility for the protection of its citizens from outside attack, lawlessness and mayhem. Underpins support for military and police force, but also a fair and just rule of law.

modules.name: Right to Bear Arms
modules.description: Confers on the citizen the right to protect their own security, and the autonomy of their civil liberties, through the use of lethal force; the balance of self-defense and libertarian detente will vary based on the society governed.

modules.name: Right to Privacy
modules.description: Confers on the citizen the reasonable expectation that their personal, civil, business and governmental records can only be made public with their consent, and that others may not profit off this information without their consent; easily enforceable 100 years ago, a difficult moving target in the digital age.

modules.name: Rights of Children
modules.description: Excluded from the electorate by age, this frames rights for children in the legal process, including most of the following: education, legal standing and due process, safety from bodily harm, adequate medical care.

modules.name: Ethical Treatment of Animals/ Endangered Species Protections
modules.description: Whether viewed as a natural resource or sentient co-citizens without a voice, this frames rights for the animal populations under the jurisdiction of the government.

modules.name: Right to an Attorney
modules.description: Grants the citizen the right to legal representation, whether they can afford it or not, as a matter of due process and civil standing.

modules.name: Prohibition of Retroactive Punishment/ Double Indemnity
modules.description: Frames a legal system that cannot try a person for the crimes of their ancestors or try one person for the same crime twice.

modules.name: Prohibiton of Cruel and Unusual Punishment
modules.description: Frames a legal system that cannot torture, humiliate, or dehumanize prisoners. Also includes general prohibitions against using prisoners for slave labor.
modules.penalty: Low Liberty, High Law & Order, High Tradition

modules.name: Right of Restorative Justice
modules.description: Conveys on citizens, whether the perpetrator or victim of a crime, the right of access to a judicial system that allows them to confront the consequences of the crime, attempt to ameliorate the damage done to all parties by that crime, and as much as possible restore the social order that existed before the crime was committed.

modules.name: Right to Die/ Right of Human Dignity
modules.description: Frames the right of every citizen in failing health to negotiate with their medical care a comfortable way to end their lives if they so choose.

modules.name: Right of Non-Citizens to Amnesty
modules.description: Constitution recognizes the human rights of non-citizen residents, immigrants or refugees to claim amnesty to remain in the country and begin the process, whether rigorous application or generational naturalization, of becoming a citizen.

modules.name: Right to Proportional Share of National Natural Resource Wealth
modules.description: Confers on citizens the right to share in any wealth, profit or dividends generated by mineral, agricultural, forestry or animal resources, to be shared through some proportional scheme, on a monthly, quarterly or annual basis.
modules.bonus: High Natural Resource Wealth,High Progressivism,High Collective

modules.name: Right to Education
modules.description: Your constitution recognizes the right of its citizens to have their children educated by a communal effort between the state and the community, paid for in some part by taxes collected by the state.

modules.name: Right to Free Speech/Free Press/Free Media/Communication
modules.description: Confers on the citizenry the right of free expression, and the ability to publish and diseminate this information in any media they see fit; inherently limited to expression that does not cause immediate demonstrable harm to others ( ie, "screaming 'fire' in a crowded theater").
modules.penalty: High Tradition, Low Science, Low Progressivisim, High Law & Order, High Authority

modules.name: Right to Assembly
modules.description: Constitution protects the ability of its citizens to gather freely in public to discuss, protest or celebrate whatever they like, as long as their behavior remains peaceful and civil.

modules.name: Right to Food/Housing
modules.description: Recognizes that the health of the state relies on the well being of its citizens, and frames the state as responsible for feeding and providing shelter for citizens unable to provide those necessities for themselves.

modules.name: Right to Employment
modules.description: Your constitution promises that the state will actively shape its economy to accomodate the employment needs of every able bodied citizen that wishes to work.

modules.name: Right to Health Care
modules.description: Recognizes the basic human right to the best medical care their society can reasonably offer to them should they become sick.

modules.name: Right to a Healthy Environment
modules.description: Frames the responsibility of the state as steward to the environment, first and foremost as a safeguard to the health and well being of its citizens.
modules.bonus: High Science, High Collective, High Progressivism
